Description: Franklin Advisers, Inc. agreed to pay $50 million and undergo compliance reforms to settle allegations that it allowed rapid in-and-out trading, known as market timing, in mutual funds it managed, contrary to fund prospectus language.

Company: Franklin Advisers, Inc. and Franklin Templeton Distributors, Inc.
Description: Franklin Advisers, Inc. and Franklin Templeton Distributors, Inc., the investment adviser and principal underwriter and distributor affiliated with the Franklin Templeton mutual funds, agreed to pay $20 million to settle allegations that, without proper disclosure, they used fund assets to compensate brokerage firms for recommending the Franklin Templeton mutual funds over others to their clients.
The SEC announced enforcement and disciplinary actions against a total of 15 firms for failure to deliver mutual fund breakpoint discounts during 2001 and 2002.

Western Asset Management, a susidiary of Legg Mason, agreed to settle allegations of concealing investor losses that resulted from a coding error and engaging in cross trading that favored some clients over others.

Legg Mason Inc. entered into a non-prosecution agreement with the Department of Justice and agreed to pay $64.2 million to resolve the Department's investigation into violations of the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act in connection with Legg Mason's participation, through a subsidiary, in a Libyan bribery scheme.
Legg Mason Inc. agreed to pay over $34 million to resolve an SEC charge that the company violated the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act in a scheme to bribe Libyan government officials.

The U.S. Department of Labor announced a settlement with Western Asset Management Company, a subsidiary of Legg Mason Inc., following investigations revealing the purchase of prohibited securities that resulted in losses to the accounts of nearly 100 employee benefit plans and investment funds holding plan assets. The settlement also resolved findings that the company engaged in prohibited cross-trading of securities in the accounts of other retirement plans and funds, which caused additional losses.

Franklin/Templeton Distributors, Inc. agreed to pay $18 million to settle a state lawsuit alleging it violated state securities laws by not adequately informing investors about agreements to pay broker-dealers to recommend and sell Franklin Templeton mutual funds.

Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division
Info Source: February 7, 2020 download of a dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php
Notes: Date and year are the Findings End Date in the dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division, which does not provide case opening or closing dates. The company name is the Legal Name provided by the dataset unless that field is blank, in which case the Trade Name is used. The dataset provides only one address and does not indicate whether it is the company headquarters address or the establishment address. The penalty amount is the total of civil monetary penalties and mandated back wages. The original dataset provides a breakdown.

Description: Franklin Resources agreed to pay more than $13 million to settle an ERISA class action alleging that the firm profited by filling its 401(k) with its own investment products.
Private Litigation Case Title: Cryer v. Franklin Resources, Inc. et al
